Waiving the Medicaid Institutions for Mental Disease (IMD) payment prohibition would free up beds in local communities’ hospitals, allowing them to better manage the surge capacity in both inpatient and emergency departments to care for COVID-19 patients.
Medicaid is the largest payer of mental health services, and expansion of this critical coverage would be vital to those who are in need, including individuals experiencing homelessness.
A critical shortage of state psychiatric beds is already forcing patients with a serious mental illness to be held in emergency rooms, hospitals, and jails while they wait for a bed.

As hospitals throughout LA County seek ways to contain the spread of COVID-19 and handle the influx of patients to be tested and treated, we cannot overlook the ongoing mental health crisis unfolding during this pandemic.

Thanks to the County’s steadfast support, we have expanded the youth suicide prevention program to 35 schools throughout the San Gabriel Valley and southeast LA County. The program serves as a model for my legislation, the Mental Health Services for Students Act (H.R. 1109).
18 years ago, I secured federal funding to place local mental health provider, Pacific Clinics, in one high school and three middle schools in LA County; one of these schools was Martha’s.

Martha went through a stage of darkness when she came to terms w/ her sexuality at age 15 and felt confused, fearful, guilty, sad & lonely, as many LGBTQ youth do. A close friend reached out to her, understood her, supported her, and encouraged her to seek mental health services.
I invite you to read my Op-Ed on the importance of funding mental health services in schools for youth like Martha, an 18 y/o Latina college student from La Puente. https://t.co/7sU0xy2soL
